Summary: N174DZ a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Delta Airlines was conducting flight DAL129 from Seattle-Tacoma Intl WA (KSEA) to Beijing/Capital China (ZBAA). Less than an hour after the departure at FL320 the flight crew declared an emergency due to an unruly passenger. A diversion back to KSEA was requested and the flight landed back to its origin without further incident.

C-FGZI a McDonnell Douglas A4N aircraft operated by Discovery Air Defence Services was conducting tactical flight SKYHAWK3 from its base in Nordholz-Spieka/Cuxhaven Germany (ETMN). Shortly after the departure at FL250 the generator failed. Since resetting the generator was not possible the Ram Air Turbine (RAT) was deployed. The pilot declared an emergency and proceeded to burn off some fuel for the landing. The aircraft returned to ETMN without further event.The operator’s maintenance discovered that the main generator failed for unknown reasons and proceeded to replace it. The aircraft was returned to service. The occurrence was also captured in the operator’s Safety Management System (SMS).

C-GHLQ a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1936 from Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL) to Casablanca/Mohammed V Intl Morocco (GMMN). During cruise flight a cabin crew member received a minor injury and was subsequently removed from further duties. Medical attention was provided through StatMD. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in GMMN without further event.

C-GHLV a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1924 from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) to London/Gatwick UK (EGKK). During cruise flight a cabin crew member became unwell and discontinued duties. Medical attention was provided through StatMD. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in EGKK without further event.

C-GOAB a private Dassault Falcon 2000EX aircraft operated by Starlink Aviation was conducting a flight from Århus/Tirstrup Denmark (EKAH) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). While in cruise flight over the Atlantic in the vicinity of 59N/046W at FL400 the flight crew received a LOW ENGINE OIL PRESSURE CAS message for the number 2 engine. The number 2 engine oil pressure was observed to fluctuate between 25 and 75 PSI and was gradually decreasing in pressure. The flight crew set the number 2 engine power to idle; when the pressure decreased below 20 PSI the flight crew shut the engine down as per the checklist and declared a PAN PAN. A diversion to Goose Bay NL (CYYR) was requested where the aircraft landed without further incident.Maintenance personnel determined that an oil leak from the generator seal on the number 2 engine caused the low oil pressure condition.

C-GFAT an Airbus 310-300 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC337 from Lisbon/Aeroporto da Portela de Sacavem Portugal (LPPT) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During cruise flight approximately 335 nautical miles East of the coast of Newfoundland the flight crew received an ECAM message advising of Yellow Hydraulic System Low Level. The flight crew completed the required checklists declared PAN PAN and continued to destination without further event.The operator’s maintenance identified and repaired the hydraulic leak at the leakage measurement isolation valve.

C-FNNU a Boeing 777-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA891 from Rome/Leonardo da Vinci Intl Italy (LIRF) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). In the early stage of the flight at cruising altitude a smell of smoke was noted in the cabin. The flight crew elected to divert to Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Germany (EDDF) where they subsequently performed an uneventful overweight landing at 285 000 Kgs. The operator is conducting an internal investigation.

C-GSGU a Cessna 208B aircraft operated by Sanders Geophysics was conducting a flight from Denpasar/Ngurah Rai - Bali Intl Indonesia (WADD) to Broome Australia (YBRM). During taxi after the landing in YBRM the aircraft experienced an engine flameout. Immediately prior to the flameout the condition lever was set to 'Low Idle' the power lever was at or near \Idle\" and the air conditioner to 'Ventilate'. There were no unusual sounds or gauge indications during the occurrence; however the ITT was observed to rise to 750° F as the engine spooled down. At this point the condition lever was brought to 'Cutoff' and the engine motored until the ITT decreased to 350° F. The aircraft was then secured as per the shutdown checklist. Subsequently the operator’s maintenance conducted a variety of checks and inspections with no faults found. Additionally multiple engine ground runs were carried out without replicating the flameout. A satisfactory test flight is to be accomplished prior to returning the aircraft to service."

C-FYJI an Airbus 319-100 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA961 from Antigua/V.C. Bird Intl Antigua and Barbuda (TAPA) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During cruise flight approximately 285 nautical miles North West of San Juan/Luis Muñoz Marín Intl Puerto Rico (TJSJ) the flight crew noticed that there was a problem with the right fuel tank feed and that the engines could be fed from the left main and center tanks only. This situation resulted in a fuel imbalance that could not be corrected. The flight crew elected to divert to TJSJ and declared a PAN PAN as a precaution. The flight crew performed an overweight landing without further event.The operator’s maintenance is investigating the cause of the fuel feed problem.

C-GWCN a Boeing 737-700 aircraft operated by WestJet was conducting flight WJA30 from Halifax/Stanfield Intl NS (CYHZ) to Glasgow/Abbotsinch UK (EGPF). During cruise flight the flight crew discovered that they were a little less than 500 lbs of fuel below the planned progression at the first fuel checkpoint. At the flight’s ETOPS exit point the aircraft was 1100 lbs below the planned fuel. During the oceanic crossing the flight crew monitored the fuel flow EGT and fuel balance and everything appeared to be normal. A fuel leak was suspected and the flight crew proceeded to shut down the APU. Approximately 40 minutes later the fuel seemed to have stabilized with 800 lbs above the required minimum to continue to EGPF. Then when the flight was 30 minutes from landing at destination the extra fuel started to decrease again. The flight crew declared a PAN PAN and requested priority handling by ATC. The aircraft landed in EGPF without further event; however the 800 extra fuel had all disappeared. ARFF checked the aircraft for leaks after the landing and did not find any.The operator is investigating the incident.

C-GOGN a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by WestJet was conducting flight WJA22 from Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) to London/Gatwick England (EGKK). During cruise flight one of the cabin crew members experienced an injury. The flight crew was notified and Medlink was contacted. The affected cabin crew member was relieved of further duties which were distributed among the remaining cabin crew members. Once at destination the individual was assessed and released by EMS.

C-FZUG an Airbus 319-100 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1760 from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) to Holguin/Frank Pais Intl Cuba (MUHG). During cruise flight the aircraft encountered an area of turbulence which caused one of the cabin crew members to be injured by a trolley. Medical advice was requested by radio and first aid has been administered by other cabin crew members. The injured individual was removed from duties for the remainder of the flight.

C-FITL a Boeing 777-300ER aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA877 from Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Germany (EDDF) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During the initial climb after departure the aircraft experienced a Centre Hydraulic failure. The flight crew requested a return to EDDF proceeded to jettison 60 tons of fuel and declared a Pan Pan. The aircraft subsequently landed without further event. The operator’s maintenance discovered that a hydraulic line was disconnected from the Center Rudder PCU Return. Repairs and checks were executed in accordance with the Aircraft Maintenance Manual (AMM) and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-FLSW a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG605 from Cayo Coco/Jardines del Rey Intl Cuba (MUCC) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). During refueling before departure at MUCC fuel spilled from the right wing. ARFF was requested and the spill was cleaned up. The flight departed and landed at destination without further incident.

C-FGZI a McDonell Douglas A4N aircraft operated by Discovery Air Defence Services was conducting a local flight from its base at Wittmund/Wittmundhafen Germany (ETNT). Approximately 70 minutes into the flight the main generator dropped offline 3 times. The Ram Air Turbine was deployed the pilot declared a PAN PAN and the aircraft returned to ETNT where it landed without further event. The incident was captured into the operator’s Safety Management System (SMS). The operator’s maintenance discovered that the DC converter failed for unknown reasons and proceeded to replace it. The aircraft was returned to service.

C-GLRN a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG349 from Cayo Coco/Jardines del Rey Intl Cuba (MUCC) to St. John’s Intl NL (CYYT). During refueling before departure at MUCC fuel spilled from the right wing. ARFF was requested and the spill eventually stopped. Subsequently the flight crew was advised by the control tower that fuel appeared to be leaking during the take off roll. The flight crew closely monitored the fuel status en route and everything appeared normal. The flight continued to destination without further incident.

C-GTQF a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC949 from Montego Bay/Sangster Intl Jamaica (MKJS) to Havana/José Martí Intl Cuba (MUHA). While the aircraft was being marshalled to Gate 13 at MUHA the left winglet came in contact with the wing of a parked Airbus A330 at Gate 12.  The operator’s maintenance removed the left winglet and the aircraft was flown back to Canada on a ferry permit. The winglet was replaced and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-GTGO a de Havilland DHC-7-100 aircraft operated by Trans Capital Air was conducting flight UN657P from Beledweyne/Beedweyne Somalia (HCMN) to Mogadishu/Aden Adde Intl Somalia (HCMM). During the climb to cruising altitude through FL120 after departure the flight crew noticed an abnormally high T5 temperature on the number 4 engine. The temperature was rising beyond normal parameters and there also was a spike in the number 4 engine torque. Since the flight crew had no control response after moving the associated engine’s power lever the engine was shut down. The flight continued to destination without further event.The operator’s maintenance replaced the Fuel Control Unit (FCU) and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-GBHZ an Airbus 319-100 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1803 from Kingston/Norman Manley Intl Jamaica (MKJP) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During cruise flight at FL340 in the vicinity of Nassau/Lynden Pindling Intl Bahamas (MYNN) the flight crew noticed an abnormal vibration associated with a noise. A few minutes later a pop was heard followed by smoke coming from the centre pedestal; an ECAM message ensued. QRH procedures were executed and an emergency was declared. The flight crew elected to divert the aircraft to MYNN where it landed without further event.The operator’s maintenance discovered a defective avionics blower fan and replaced it in accordance with the Aircraft Maintenance Manual (AMM). After successful tests were carried out the aircraft was returned to service.

C-GBZR a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1831 from Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) to Honolulu Intl HI (PHNL). During cruise flight at FL350 at approximately N4430 W135 the cabin crew detected smoke in the forward galley. The source of the smoke was identified as a utility light. A cabin crew member discharged a halon extinguisher and the flight crew deactivated the corresponding electrical circuit as a precaution. The flight crew declared a PAN PAN and diverted the flight to Portland Intl OR (KPDX) where the aircraft landed without further event.The air operator captured the incident in their Safety Management System (SMS) and is investigating.

C-GTVF a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG683 from Varadero/Juan Gualberto Gómez Intl Cuba (MUVR) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During the fuelling process before departure in MUVR a fuel spill occurred from the right wing. ARFF attended and monitored the clean up. An engineer completed a serviceability check of the fuel valves system and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-FTZD a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG725 from Liberia/Daniel Oduber Quirós Intl Costa Rica (MRLB) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During cruise flight one of the cabin crew members became ill and was unable to continue their duties. The flight continued to destination without further event.

C-GOGN a Boeing 767-338 aircraft operated by WestJet was conducting flight WJA4 from London/Gatwick UK (EGKK) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). Shortly after takeoff at 4000 feet a black drone passed to the right of the aircraft approximately 100 feet above. The drone had an object hanging off it. The flight crew notified ATC and the flight continued to destination without further event.

C-GTSO an Airbus 330-342 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC139 from Cayo Coco/Jardines del Rey Intl Cuba (MUCC) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). During the takeoff sequence one of the cabin crew members became ill and was unable to continue their duties. The flight continued to destination without further event.

C-FYJD a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG737 from Montego Bay/Sangster Intl Jamaica (MKJS) to Calgary Intl AB (CYYC). After the refueling procedure was completed during the pre-departure set up the flight crew noticed an abnormal behavior of the fuel gauges. The operator’s Maintenance Control Centre (MCC) was consulted and instructed the flight crew to have the fuel verified for contamination. The sample revealed that the fuel was contaminated with water by more than 30%. The passengers were deplaned and maintenance personnel proceeded to drain all water from the reservoirs. The flight subsequently departed and reached its destination without further event.

C-FTDW a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG375 from Varadero/Juan Gualberto Gómez Intl Cuba (MUVR) to London ON (CYXU). When approximately 40 nautical miles North North-West of MUVR at FL210 the flight crew noticed traffic coming towards them at the same altitude. The flight crew confirmed the altitude with Havana Center and received clearance to turn to a heading 070°. As SWG375 was in the turn the flight crew received a TCAS RA to descend. Compliance with the RA was executed and when clear of traffic the flight returned to FL210. The aircraft continued to its destination without further incident.

C-FGZO a McDonnell Douglas A4N Skyhawk aircraft operated by Discovery Air Defence Services was conducting a military mission with the German Air Force from its home base in Wittmund/Wittmundhafen Germany (ETNT). Shortly after takeoff ATC advised the pilot that parts of the aircraft tire have been found on the runway. The pilot performed a low fly by the tower for a visual checkout of the landing gear; however nothing abnormal was noticed. One of the other jets was able to join C-FGZO to perform a visual inspection and noticed a slightly deformed left tire. The pilot of C-FGZO then declared an emergency and after burning excess fuel landed without further event.

ET-AOQ a Boeing 787-8 aircraft operated by Ethiopian Airlines was conducting flight ETH501 from Washington/Dulles Intl VA (KIAD) to Addis Ababa/Bole Intl Ethiopia (HAAB). During cruise flight in oceanic airspace crossing 46N/033W a crew member became ill. The flight crew requested a diversion to Terceira/Aeroporto das Lajes Portugal (LPLA) and transferred to Shanwick Radio for further air traffic control instruction.

C-GFAJ an Airbus 330-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA824 from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) to Amsterdam/Schiphol Netherlands (EHAM). During the flight the green hydraulic system experienced a leak. The flight crew executed the relevant checklist and ECAM items and continued to destination. As the landing gear was extended on the approach to Runway 18R at EHAM the flight crew received a Low Green Hydraulic Quantity message and declared a MAYDAY. The flight landed without further event and was met by ARFF. A tug was required to tow the aircraft off the runway and to the gate. The operator’s maintenance replaced an O-Ring on the Green Hydraulic System Service Manifold. The system was then serviced and checked for leaks. The aircraft was returned to service.

C-GQCH a Sikorsky S-92A aircraft operated by Cougar Helicopters was conducting flight CHI41 on an IFR flight from St. John’s Intl NL (CYYT) to the Henry Goodrich offshore platform (HGR). When approximately 5 nautical miles from HGR the flight crew selected the landing gear down and received a master caution warning HYDRAULIC #3 FAIL. The flight crew observed the pressure gauge at zero on the corresponding system. A missed approach in VMC was carried out and the flight crew elected to return to CYYT declaring a PAN PAN as a precaution. The passengers were briefed and an emergency landing gear extension was carried out. The aircraft landed without further incident at CYYT.

On 07 March 2017 a WestJet Boeing 737-800 aircraft (registration C-GWSV serial number 37158) operating as flight 2652 (WJA2652) was conducting a scheduled instrument flight rules flight from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson International Airport Ontario to Princess Juliana International Airport St. Maarten Netherlands Antilles. During the approach to Runway 10 the aircraft deviated from the normal descent path. At 1534 Atlantic Standard Time (AST) when the aircraft was 0.30 nautical miles from the runway threshold and had descended to an altitude of 40 feet above the water the crew initiated a missed approach. Given that visibility was below the limits for conducting a second approach the flight was cleared to hold until it had improved. Following an improvement in visibility the crew conducted a second approach and landed at 1618 AST without further incident.

C-GOWG a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG317 from Santa Clara/Abel Santamaria Cuba (MUSC) to Quebec/Jean Lesage Intl QC (CYQB). As the cabin crew was preparing for the meal service during cruise flight a burning smell was noticed and smoke was visible coming out from oven number 2 in the forward galley. Emergency equipment was gathered as a precaution and the oven was immediately turned off; the smoke then dissipated. The cabin crew discovered that part of the meal in the lower tray was burnt. The situation was monitored and the flight crew was kept informed periodically. The flight continued to destination without further incident.

C-FRZZ a privately operated Cessna 210 aircraft was conducting a flight from Guatemala City/La Aurora Intl Guatemala (MGGT) to Quezaltenango/Los Altos Guatemala (MGQZ). Upon touchdown at MGQZ the landing gear collapsed and the aircraft departed the side of the runway. The aircraft sustained substantial damage its belly. The DGAC Guatemala is investigating.

C-FWGH a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG313 from Santa Clara/Abel Santamaria Cuba (MUSC) to Ottawa/MacDonald-Cartier Intl ON (CYOW). During refueling at MUSC the right wing was over fueled and fuel spilled from the overflow vent. ARFF was called to clean up the spill and fuel was transferred to the left tank to stop the overfill. The aircraft was towed to a different parking position and ARFF stood by until the aircraft departed.

C-FNND a Boeing 777-200 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA16 from Hong Kong International - Chek Lap Kok China (VHHH) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). While enroute approximately 450 nautical miles east of New Sapporo Intl Japan (RJCC) the flight crew received EICAS advisories for HYD QTY LOW L followed by HYD PRESS PRI L. The left hydraulic reservoir quantity was displaying zero. The QRH was actioned a PAN PAN was declared and a diversion to Tokyo/Haneda Japan (RJTT) was initiated. Fuel was jettisoned prior to the arrival and the aircraft landed within normal weight limits.The operator’s maintenance discovered that the Engine Driven Pump (EDP) casing was cracked. The EDP the return case and the drain-pressure filters were all replaced. The hydraulic system was replenished and was checked serviceable. The aircraft was returned to service.

C-GZUG a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG626 from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) to Varadero/Juan Gualberto Gómez Intl Cuba (MUVR). During the descent the flight was cleared to FL190 after waypoint TADPO however the flight crew received a TCAS Resolution Advisory (RA) to \Level Off\". The descent was stopped at FL195 and the flight crew reported the occurrence to Havana Center. The flight continued to destination and landed without further event."

C-FTAH a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG785 from La Ceiba/Golosón Intl Honduras (MHLC) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). Upon departure from MHLC the flight had been cleared to FL330. While climbing through 2000 feet ATC called \SWG785 traffic level 3500\". The flight crew queried ATC if they wanted them level at 3500 feet and ATC repeated the same instruction. Climbing through 3200 feet the flight crew reduced the rate of climb and queried ATC again. As SWG785 leveled off at 3500 feet a TCAS RA – CLIMB was received. The flight crew notified ATC of the TCAS RA told them they were unable to maintain 3500 feet and that they were climbing. Conditions were VMC and the traffic was in sight."

C-GTSR an Airbus A330-200 aircraft operated by Air Transat on behalf of Air Caraibes was conducting flight FWI514 from Paris/Orly France (LFPO) to Fort de France/Aimé Césaire Intl Martinique (TFFF). Just prior to the descent into TFFF one of the cabin crew members became ill and was unable to continue their duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in TFFF without further event.

C-GFAJ an Airbus 330-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA833 from Brussels Belgium (EBBR) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). During the take-off run from Runway 07L the forward right hand wheel of the right main landing gear failed and separated. The flight crew heard a loud bang associated with an ECAM warning BRAKE that came on simultaneously. The flight crew rejected the takeoff at 82 knots declared a PAN PAN and requested ARFF at the aircraft. The deceleration did not occur as expected since one thrust reverser did not deploy due to the loss of hydraulic pressure. The aircraft vacated the runway at Taxiway C1 and was shut down. There were no injuries.Debris were scattered on the whole length of the runway including the intersection of Runway 01. The operator’s maintenance found damage to the number 1 engine nose cowl. The right hand main landing gear bogie requires replacement.

C-FIGR a Kamov KA-32A11BC aircraft operated by VIH Helicopters was conducting forest fire suppression operations in Chile with 2 pilots on board. As the aircraft was returning after a water drop the crew heard a loud bang. There were no warning lights and no mechanical abnormalities were noted. The flight crew initially determined that they experienced a bird strike and returned to base where the helicopter landed with no further events. Maintenance personnel performed an inspection and found minor damage to the front avionics door. No evidence of a bird strike could be found however a tear in the skin of the helicopter as opposed to a dent was identified. Additionally evidence consistent with a plastic smear on the paint as well as damage to the door’s lower hinge was found. The operator suspects a collision with a hard object similar to a drone.

C-FWGH a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG396 from Manzanillo/Playa de Oro Intl Mexico (MMZO) to Regina Intl SK (CYQR). While refueling before departure in MMZO the right main tank was overfilled and fuel spilled out. The flight crew requested Emergency Services to the aircraft to clean the spill. The flight proceeded without further incident.

F-HAVN a Boeing 757-200 aircraft operated by OpenSkies was conducting flight BOS5 from Paris/Orly France (LPFO) to New York/JFK Intl NY (KJFK). During cruise at FL370 the flight crew received a TCAS Resolution Advisory (RA) and climbed to FL375. M-MSGG a privately operated Bombardier CL-600-2B16 aircraft operating from London/Stansted England (EGSS) to Bangor Intl ME (KBGR) was flying 1000 feet below BOS5. The TCAS RA of BOS5 was triggered by a 200 feet altitude deviation by M-MSGG due to moderate to severe turbulence. Both aircraft continued without further incident.

C-GTSN an Airbus 330-200 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TVP7602 on behalf of Travel Services from Warsaw/Fryderyk Chopin Intl Poland (EPWA) to Varadero/Juan Gualberto Gómez Intl Cuba (MUVR). Shortly after takeoff from EPWA the flight crew received a brake overheat message on the ECAM. The flight crew executed the ECAM procedure and extended the landing gear. Once the temperature came down to acceptable parameters the landing gear was then retracted. However the temperature started to rise once more beyond normal range. The landing gear was extended again and the flight crew requested a return to EPWA. ARFF services were requested for the landing and inspected the brakes. No issues were found.The operator’s maintenance replaced the number 5 brake assembly in accordance with AMM 32-42-27. Additionally the number 5 main wheel assembly was also replaced in accordance with AMM 32-41-11.

C-FRAM a Boeing 777-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA88 from Shanghai/Pudong Intl China (ZSPD) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During cruise flight two cabin crew members felt unwell and were unable to continue with their duties. Six other cabin crew members reported feeling ill however continued working. All cabin crew members were referred to a doctor travelling on board; no conclusive cause could be identified. The operator is monitoring the situation.

C-FNOI a Boeing 787-9 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA71 from New Delhi/Indira Gandhi Intl India (VIDP) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). Shortly after departure in the vicinity of Kabul/Hamid Karzai Intl Afghanistan (OAKB) one of the cabin crew members became unwell and discontinued duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in CYYZ without further event.

C-FTCA a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA889 from London/Heathrow England (EGLL) to Ottawa/MacDonald-Cartier Intl ON (CYOW). Shortly after departure one of the cabin crew members became unwell and discontinued duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in CYOW without further event.

C-FIVM a Boeing 777-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA32 from Beijing/Capital China (ZBAA) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). Approximately 415 nautical miles North of Khabarovsk Russia (UHHH) the aircraft encountered two bouts of severe clear air turbulence each lasting less than 60 seconds. The flight crew reported the sensation during onset was similar to that of a mountain wave. During the incident one of the flight crew member’s head struck an overhead map light resulting in a minor laceration. The seatbelt sign was immediately switched on and no injuries were reported in the cabin. No loss of control was reported.

C-FFWM an Airbus A320-200 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA1561 from Cancun Intl Mexico (MMUN) to Ottawa/MacDonald-Cartier Intl ON (CYOW). After the departure from MMUN the flight crew received an ECAM warning message for SMOKE LAVATORY SMOKE while climbing through 5000 feet. A PAN PAN was declared and the flight returned to MMUN with emergency services on standby. Subsequently the operator’s maintenance replaced the smoke detector control unit and the smoke detectors in lavatories E & D. All units functioned properly and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-FEWJ a Boeing 737-700 aircraft operated by WestJet was conducting flight WJA2378 from Calgary Intl AB (CYYC) to Bahías de Huatulco Intl Mexico (MMBT). Prior to descent a cabin crew member suffered a work related injury and was unable to continue with their duties. Duties were distributed to the remaining cabin crew members for the flight; EMS met the flight at destination.

C-GVIJ a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Cargojet Airways was conducting flight CJT1893 from Halifax/Stanfield Intl NS (CYHZ) to Cologne-Bonn/Konrad Adenauer Germany (EDDK). During the final approach sequence to Runway 32R at EDDK the flight crew received a TE FLAPS DISAGREE EICAS message upon selection of Flaps 20. A missed approach was executed and the flight crew declared an emergency. The TE FLAP DISAGREE checklist was completed while ATC vectored the flight for a second approach. A Flaps 20 landing was performed using alternate flaps and the flight landed without further event. ARFF checked the brake temperature after landing and none were high. The aircraft then taxied to its parking position. The operator’s maintenance found the number 7 Transmission Torque Limiter tripped. The transmission was replaced and the flaps were functioned checked serviceable as per B767 FIM 27-51. After a satisfactory test flight the aircraft was released back to service. However the aircraft was involved in a similar event on the following flight while landing in Hamilton ON (CYHM) on 29 December 2016.

C-FFWM an Airbus 320-200 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA1561 from Cancún Intl Mexico (MMUN) to Ottawa/MacDonald-Cartier Intl ON (CYOW). While on the ground in MMUN the flight crew received smoke detection alerts from both a cargo bay and a lavatory. The operator’s maintenance cleared the messages by performing Fault Isolation Manual Procedure 26-17-00-810-801A. All tests were satisfactory no faults were detected and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-GWAZ a Boeing B737-700 aircraft operated by WestJet was conducting flight WJA2206 from Edmonton Intl AB (CYEG) to Cancún Intl Mexico (MMUN). During cruise flight one of the cabin crew members experienced a medical incident. The flight crew was notified and MEDLINK was contacted. Duties were distributed to the remainder of the cabin crew for the landing in MMUN and EMS met the aircraft upon arrival.

N288ZJ a Bombardier BD-700-1A10 (Global Express) aircraft operated by Zetta Jet was conducting a flight to reposition the aircraft from Tucson Intl AZ (KTUS) to Farnborough UK (EGLF). While in cruise flight at FL450 near 50°N/047°W the flight crew noticed a bright flash accompanied by a loud bang coming from the first officer’s windshield. A R WINDSHIELD FAIL message was received and the flight crew noted that the outer layer of the first officer’s windshield had shattered. The crew donned their oxygen masks and elected to descend and divert to St. John’s Intl NL (CYYT). Initial radio contact with Gander ACC was unsuccessful and the flight crew executed contingency procedures for the turn and the descent. The transponder was set to 7700 messages were relayed through a commercial airliner and a clearance for the return to CYYT was given. When radio contact was established the emergency was cancelled and the flight landed at CYYT without further incident.Maintenance personnel inspected the aircraft and prepared it for flight to a facility for replacement of the damaged windshield.

C-FPIJ a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Cargojet Airways was conducting flight CJT1894 from Cologne-Bonn/Konrad Adenauer Germany (EDDK) to Hamilton ON (CYHM). After the departure from EDDK the flight crew experienced an in-flight engine shutdown. The EICAS displayed an R ENG OIL PRESS advisory message. The appropriate QRH procedure was carried out and resulted in an in-flight shut down of the number 2 engine. An emergency was declared and the aircraft returned to land at EDDK without further incident. No injuries or damage to the aircraft were reported.  Subsequent maintenance inspection revealed a significant oil leak at the aft end of the engine core. The source of the leak was determined to be a broken oil line at the \Lube Oil Manifold\" connection of the Oil Pressure Transmitter. The line was replaced the engine was test run and the aircraft was released back to service. The aircraft experienced a similar event the following day (see A16F0215)."

C-FPIJ a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Cargojet Airways was conducting flight CJT1894 from Cologne-Bonn/Konrad Adenauer Germany (EDDK) to Hamilton ON (CYHM). After the departure from EDDK the flight crew experienced an in-flight engine shutdown. The EICAS displayed an R ENG OIL PRESS advisory message. The appropriate QRH procedure was carried out and resulted in an in-flight shut down of the number 2 engine. An emergency was declared and the aircraft returned to land at EDDK without further incident. No injuries or damage to the aircraft were reported.  The operator’s maintenance discovered that the oil line at the \Lube Oil Manifold\" connection of the Oil Pressure Transmitter which had been replaced as a result of the 11 December 2016 occurrence (see A16F0216) had again failed. However in addition to the oil line an associated oil line support clamp was also found broken. In all likelihood the support clamp had been broken prior to the previous occurrence however was not discovered during maintenance activities. Both the oil line and clamp were replaced the engine was test run and the aircraft was released back to service. Consequently the operator initiated a fleet campaign to inspect the condition of the oil line and clamp prior to the next flight. Additionally the incorporation of applicable GE Service Bulletins 79-0082 and 79-0086 has been mandated during all engine shop visits."

C-GCTS an Airbus A330-300 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC734 from Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL) to Punta Cana Intl Dominican Republic (MDPC). During cruise flight one of the cabin crew members became ill and was unable to continue their duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in MDPC without further event.

C-FXPL an Aerospatiale AS350 B3 helicopter operated by Sander Geophysics was conducting survey line operations North East of Luang Prabang Intl Laos (VLLB). During the first flight of the day the Gradient Mag bird collided with the top of a high peak at low speed. The Mag bird tow cable disconnected and the Mag bird came to rest on the side of the mountain. The flight crew circled around and found an appropriate landing site where the tow cable was reattached to the helicopter. The Mag bird was flown to the nearest suitable landing site for inspection. The nose cone appeared to be the only damage and a quick fix was made to allow the bird to be returned to base at VLLB where permanent repairs were made to the equipment. The operator will amend the procedure and update training to address the incident.

C-GBDA a Great Slave Helicopters AS 350 B3 helicopter was performing aerial work in Región del Libertador Chile. During the initial stages of a slinging operation while tensioning the line with an unloaded hook the sling contacted an individual who was assisting with the slinging operation. The individual was raised off the ground approximately 15 meters before falling and sustaining serious injuries. The Directorate General of Civil Aeronautics - Chile has initiated an investigation.

C-FYKW an Airbus A319-114 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1807 from San José/Juan Santamaría Intl Costa Rica (MROC) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). Shortly after takeoff from Runway 25 on an assigned heading of 210° in Instrument Meteorological Conditions (IMC) the flight crew received a TCAS TA aural warning for conflicting traffic which was observed on the cockpit display to be within 1 nautical mile and less than 1000 feet above in descent. The flight crew of ROU1807 decreased the rate of climb and the traffic passed directly overhead. The actual vertical separation is currently unknown. It is believed that the TCAS RA did not annunciate due to inhibition during the initial climb phase of flight.  The incident occurred following a significant weather system in the area which resulted in numerous flight disruptions and subsequent abnormally high levels of air traffic. At the time of the event MROC departures and arrivals were reported to have been conducted to and from both ends of the airport’s single runway.

G-DAJC a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Condor Airline was conducting flight CFG199 from Varadero/Juan Gualberto Gómez Intl Cuba (MUVR) to Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Germany (EDDF). While in cruise flight at about 50°N/045°W the flight crew received a R AC BUS off indication and noted that R GEN was off line. The flight crew reset as per the QRH and the system fault recurred. An emergency was declared and as per contingency procedures the flight crew descended and proceeded to divert to Gander Intl NL (CYQX). ATC issued a clearance for direct to CYQX and the flight landed without incident.

C-FTDW a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Sunwing Airlines was conducting flight SWG410 from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) to Puerto Plata/Gregorio Luperón Intl Dominican Republic (MDPP). During the descent into MDPP a large motionless thunderstorm cell was located directly overhead the airport and approaches to either side of the single runway were not possible. The flight crew elected to enter a hold and wait for the weather system to move away however since there was no improvement the decision was made to proceed to the alternate. When the flight was established on final at Samaná/El Catey Intl Dominican Republic (MDCY) the flight crew declared a Low Fuel Emergency. The aircraft landed at MDCY without further event.

C-GEOU a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA91 from São Paulo/Guarulhos Intl Brazil (SBGR) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). During the climb to cruising altitude approximately 100 nautical miles North of Viracopos-Campinas Intl Brazil (SBKP) the flight crew noted an acrid odour in the cockpit. A MAYDAY was declared and a return to SBGR was requested where the aircraft landed without further event.The operator’s maintenance determined that the odour was coming from the right-hand window number 1 Terminal Block Connector J5 as there were signs of window seal discoloration. The window was replaced in accordance with AMM 56-11-01. Additionally the window heat controller unit was replaced in accordance with AMM 30-41-01. The aircraft was returned to service.

C-FIYE a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was conducting flight ROU1944 from Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) to Bogotá/El Nuevo Dorado Intl Colombia (SKBO). During the cruise phase of flight at FL350 in layer clouds and smooth air the flight unexpectedly encountered moderate turbulence for approximately 1 to 2 minutes. As there were no forecast or on-board weather radar indications of turbulence the cabin crew was not prepared for the encounter. The seatbelt sign was immediately turned on but two flight attendants situated in the rear of the aircraft have reportedly sustained injury during the encounter. One flight attendant was deemed “incapacitated” and relieved of their duties. The flight was completed without further event.

C-GWRG a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by WestJet was conducting flight WJA1852 from Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) to Kahului HI (PHOG). During cruise flight one of the cabin crew members became unwell and discontinued duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in PHOG without further event.

N2740B a Cessna 421 aircraft was en route from Goose Bay Newfoundland and Labrador (CYYR) to Narsarsuaq Greenland (BGBW) at flight level 210 when the pilot reported a loss of oil from the left engine. The flight was at 59N 048W when it lost engine power. The pilot shut down the engine and declared an emergency. The pilot continued on to Greenland but diverted to Paamiut airport (BGPT) due to poor weather at BGBW and landed safely.

The Ken Borek Air Ltd Douglas DC3T C-FMKB was tasked with moving a fuel cache from S 79 46' 21.00\ E 157 45' 35.40\" to a location that did not accumulate snow. The current location had been used for approximately 10 years and required that the drums be dug out of the snow every six weeks. The plan was to move the cache to a \"blue ice\" area. This is an area of the glacier that is wind swept and does not accumulate snow. The first load was loaded and the aircraft lifted off to search for a new site by air. A suitable site was located 4 nm from the point of departure. On the return trip it was decided that once the fuel drums were loaded they would attempt to taxi the 4nm to the new site since it was so close. It was 1200 meters into this trip that the left main gear struck a snow covered hard packed snow drift causing the left main gear to slowly collapse. As the aircraft began to veer to the left the crew realized what was happening and immediately shutdown the left engine to protect the engine and propeller. The left wing came to rest on the snow. The damage appears to be limited to the left gear and wing. An additional aircraft was dispatched to the site and arrived 1 hour and 20 minutes later to recover the flight crew and passengers. All involved returned to base without incident. There were no injuries and no hazardous material was released."

C-GMCP a Learjet 45 aircraft operated by Skyservice Business Aviation was conducting a Medevac flight from Accra/Kotoka Intl Ghana (DGAA) to Dakar/Léopold Sédar Senghor Intl Senegal (GOOY). Just before reaching cruise altitude after departure one of the flight crew members became incapacitated and was unable to continue their duties. The controls were transferred to the other pilot and the incapacitated pilot left the cockpit where he was attended by the medical crew in the cabin. The flight continued to GOOY with a single pilot who was assisted by another member of the medical crew. The aircraft landed without further event.

C-FNOE a Boeing 787-9 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA25 from Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) to Shanghai/Pudong Intl China (ZSPD). An extensive re-route was issued by Shenyang Control (ZYSH) towards the direction of Beijing when ACA25 was overhead the HRB VOR-DME (Harbin) approximately 130 nautical miles North East of Beijing. This re-route created a low fuel situation which prompted the flight crew to declare a PAN PAN and the flight received priority ATC handling direct to ZSPD. The aircraft landed without further event and shut down at the gate with 5100 kgs of fuel remaining. The CAAC met the aircraft and decided that an investigation will not be conducted.

EZ-A777 a Boeing 777-200LR aircraft operated by Turkmenistan Airlines was conducting flight TUA3777 from Atlanta/Hartsfield-Jackson Intl GA (KATL) to Ashgabat Intl Turkmenistan (UTAA). While in cruise flight at about 61°N / 039° W the flight crew reported a low number 1 engine oil quantity indication and requested a lower altitude. Approximately 13 minutes later the flight crew declared a PAN PAN and requested to divert to Keflavik Intl Greenland (BIKF). The flight landed one hour and ten minutes later with no further reported incident.

N662UA a Boeing B767-322 aircraft operated by United Airlines was conducting flight UAL51 from Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR) to Adolfo Suárez Madrid-Barajas Intl Spain (LEMD). While in cruise flight at FL340 the first officer's windshield cracked. The crew declared an emergency and requested a return back to KEWR where the aircraft landed without further incident.The operator’s maintenance replaced the windshield and returned the aircraft to service.

C-FXCA a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA895 from Milan/Malpensa Italy (LIMC) to Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ). Through 90 Kts on the takeoff roll the flight crew rejected the takeoff due to the failure of the Captain's analog airspeed indicator. ARFF responded as a precaution to monitor and inspect brake temperature and released the aircraft to taxi back to the gate. There were no reported injuries. The operator's maintenance replaced the airspeed indicator as per AMM 34-13-02 and the aircraft was released to service.

C-GFAH an Airbus 330-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA833 from Brussels Belgium (EBBR) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). While in cruise flight in the vicinity of N5430/W040 one of the cabin crew members became unwell and discontinued duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in CYUL without further event.

C-GGTS an Airbus A330-200 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC699 from Athens/Eleftherios Venizelos Intl Greece (LGAV) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). While in cruise flight during the oceanic crossing one of the cabin crew members became ill and was unable to continue their duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in CYUL without further event.

C-GTSD an Airbus A330-300 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC279 from Paris/Charles de Gaulle France (LFPG) to Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). While in cruise flight during the oceanic crossing one of the cabin crew members became ill and was unable to continue their duties. Positions were reassigned among the other cabin crew members for the remainder of the flight. The aircraft landed in CYUL uneventfully.

C-FCAF a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada was conducting flight ACA2128 from Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL) to Lyon/St-Exupéry France (LFLL). During the approach to LFLL the flight crew received a \LE FLAP ASYM\" EICAS warning message after selecting Flap 20. A missed approach was initiated and the QRH was actioned. The flight crew declared a PAN PAN and the flight returned to land on Runway 36L without further incident. The operator’s maintenance replaced the Flap Slat Electronic Unit in accordance with AMM 27-51-01. The aircraft was checked serviceable and was returned to service."

N276AY an Airbus A330-300 aircraft operated by American Airlines was conducting flight AAL719 from Rome/Leonardo da Vinci Intl Italy (LIRF) to Philadelphia Intl PA (KPHL). While in cruise flight at about 60°07'N 032°52'W the crew noted a Low Crew Oxygen pressure indication and requested to divert to Shannon Intl Ireland (EINN). Since a clearance could not be granted the flight crew followed the prescribed contingency procedures and began to descend. An emergency was declared and then a diversion to Gander Intl NL (CYQX) was requested. Once the flight levelled at FL100 AAL719 advised that they were no longer in an emergency situation and the flight continued to CYQX where it landed without further incident.The operator’s maintenance isolated an oxygen leak in the Captain’s mask and replaced the mask assembly. The crew oxygen bottle was serviced and the system was tested serviceable.

N783AM a Boeing 787-8 aircraft operated by AeroMéxico was conducting flight AMX003 from Mexico City/Benito Juárez Intl Mexico (MMMX) to Paris/Charles de Gaulle France (LFPG). During cruise flight at lat/long 47°39'N/034°36'W an automated emergency message was sent to Gander Oceanic Centre declaring a MAYDAY due to an engine failure and a diversion to Gander Intl NL (CYQX). After Gander ATC sent the clearance they received several automated reports indicating that the flight was proceeding eastbound that operations were normal and that the flight was continuing to destination. Shortly thereafter Gander ATC received a message indicating that the emergency message was sent with no apparent reason.

N662UA a Boeing 767-300 aircraft operated by United Airlines was conducting flight UAL865 from Hamburg/Fuhlsbüttel Germany (EDDH) to Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR). During cruise flight over the Atlantic Ocean the number 2 generator tripped off-line. The crew's attempts to reset the generator were unsuccessful. The crew initiated a descent in order to start the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU); however they received an APU Fault indication that required shutting it down. An emergency was declared and the crew requested a diversion to Goose Bay NL (CYYR) where UAL865 landed without further incident.The operator’s maintenance determined that the number 2 generator was faulty and was replaced. The APU had an oil leak which could not be rectified at CYYR. The APU was deferred in accordance with the operator's Minimum Equipment List (MEL) and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-FOGJ a Boeing 767-300 operated by WestJet was operating as flight WJA027 from London/Gatwick England (EGKK) to Edmonton Intl AB (CYEG). During cruise flight the aircraft experienced banging and vibrations from the number 1 engine (General Electric CF6-80C2B6). The flight crew reduced the thrust and elected to divert to Keflavik Iceland (BIKF). Prior to landing fuel was dumped and an emergency was declared. The aircraft landed without further event and the engine was removed from service for inspection.

C-FDAT an Airbus 310-308 operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TSC132 en route from Montreal/Pierre Elliot Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL) to Toulouse/Blagnac France (LFBO) when a flight attendant became ill and was unable to continue duties. The positions were reassigned for the remainder of the flight.

C-GJVY an Airbus A319-112 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge as flight ROU1948 was on the initial approach of a scheduled flight from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to Panama City/Tocumen Intl Panama (MPTO). While maintaining 6 000 feet on radar vectors the TCAS identified a target a Boeing 737 operated by COPA Airlines as flight 109 almost directly above at 8 000 feet and flying the same track. The B737 began descending until approximately 1 000 feet above ROU1948 at which point the TCAS target changed to solid white. The Flight Crew then noted that COPA109 continued through 1 000 feet vertical separation. While in communication with ATC regarding the traffic a TCAS TA was received followed by an immediate TCAS RA to descend. The PF immediately disconnected the autopilot called for Flight Directors off and initiated an avoidance descent while the PM notified ATC of the RA compliance. ATC communicated with COPA109 which subsequently leveled at 6 000 feet. ROU1948 leveled at 5 000 feet and completed the flight without further incident.

C-GRNN a De Havilland DHC-8-106 operated by PAL Aerospace Ltd. was on the climb out from Aeropuerto Hato - Willemstad Curaçao (TNCC) when the number one engine oil pressure was noted at 20 psi. The engine was shut down and the aircraft circled north of the airport to complete the required checklists. The aircraft returned to TNCC and landed on RWY 11. It stopped on taxiway A east and the number 2 engine was shut down. The aircraft was subsequently towed to the coast guard platform.

N673UA a Boeing 767-322 aircraft operated by United Airlines was conducting flight UAL30 from Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR) to Munich/Franz Josef Strauss Intl Germany (EDDM). During cruise flight in the vicinity of 46N050W the crew selected the flight management computer to provide a course offset to the right; however the aircraft began to deviate to the left. The crew was unable to correct using the flight management computer and selecting the backup routing also introduced an error. The crew requested a clearance to return to KEWR due to navigational problems but due to traffic ATC was unable to provide the request. The crew elected to declare an emergency and deviated without a clearance in accordance with in-flight contingency procedures. Once level at FL300 the flight received a clearance to return to KEWR where a landing was made without further incident.The operator’s maintenance found that the right High Frequency Transceiver had failed and proceeded to replace it. All subsequent checks were accomplished and no further discrepancies were noted.

F-HAVI a Boeing 757-200 aircraft operated by OpenSkies was conducting flight BOS3 from Paris/Orly France (LFPO) to Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR). When in cruise flight approximately 225 nautical miles North East of Gander Intl NL (CYQX) the crew received a WHEEL WELL FIRE EICAS indication. QRH actions were completed a MAYDAY was declared and coordination with ATC for a diversion to CYQX was executed. The Wheel Well Fire warning indication ceased approximately 15 minutes later and the flight landed in CYQX without further incident.ARFF personnel inspected both main landing gear areas and no evidence of heat or fire was noted. The operator’s maintenance determined that the Wheel Well Fire Warning System was faulty.

N781UA a Boeing 777-200 aircraft operated by United Airlines was conducting flight UAL999 from Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR) to Brussels Belgium (EBBR). When in cruise flight at FL380 and approximately 580 nautical miles East of Gander Intl NL (CYQX) a flight attendant reported fumes to the flight crew. It was determined that the odour was contained to the first class inboard lavatory. The flight crew decided to don their oxygen masks and requested a diversion to CYQX. Due to traffic ATC was unable to provide a clearance. The crew elected to declare an emergency and deviated without a clearance in accordance with in-flight contingency procedures. Once level at FL300 the flight received a clearance for CYQX where it landed without further incident or reported injuries.Maintenance personnel found no evidence of smoke or heat and determined that the trash container was the source of the odour.

C-FNOE a Boeing 787-9 operated by Air Canada as flight ACA84 from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to Tel Aviv/Ben Gurion Intl Israel (LLBG) was in cruise flight at FL370 approximately 75 nautical miles South of Cork Ireland when the EICAS generated a \CREW OXYGEN LOW\" alert. The crew declared a MAYDAY and diverted to London/Heathrow England (EGLL) for maintenance action."

C-GHQY a Boeing 787-8 aircraft operated by Air Canada as flight AC35 from Vancouver Intl. (CYVR) was enroute to Brisbane International Airport (YBBN) when a flight attendant became incapacitated and was unable to their continue duties.

C-FGZH a McDonnell Douglas A4N aircraft operated by Discovery Air Defence Services experienced a generator failure approximately twenty minutes after departure from Wittmundhafen Air Base Germany (ETNT). The generator was successfully reset twice however after a third failure the generator could not be reset. Subsequently the Ram Air Turbine was successfully deployed to provide power to the aircraft. The mission was immediately terminated an emergency was declared and the aircraft returned to ETNT without any further incident.

C-GTSH an Airbus A310-300 aircraft operated by Air Transat was conducting flight TS281 from Barcelona/El Prat Spain (LEBL) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). While cruising at FL310 the crew received an ECAM message - YELLOW HYD RESERVOIR LOW LEVEL. ECAM actions and Task Management procedures were accomplished after which the flight was diverted to Paris/Charles de Gaulle Intl France (LFPG). A PAN PAN was declared and assistance requested to be on standby for the landing. The landing was uneventful.

B-2031 a Boeing 777-300ER operated by Air China was conducting flight CCA888 from Los Angeles Intl CA (KLAX) to Beijing/Capital Intl China (ZBAA). While transiting through Canadian airspace approximately 360 nautical miles West of Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) the flight crew reported a medical emergency. The crew coordinated fuel dumping and requested a diversion to CYVR.

C-GEOQ a B767-300 aircraft operated by Air Canada as flight AC92 from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to Santiago/Arturo Merino Benítez Intl Chile (SCEL) was in cruise flight at FL370 when a TCAS/RA to descend was received approximately 40 nautical miles South East of the TOY VOR (Tongoy) Chile. The conflicting traffic was in opposite direction passing FL373 for FL380. The crew executed a descent of 500 feet per RA guidance.

C-GGTS an Airbus A330-243 aircraft operated by Air Transat as flight TSC538 from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to London/Gatwick Intl UK (EGKK) was in cruise flight approximately 250 nautical miles west of EGKK when a flight attendant became ill and was unable to continue duties. The remaining cabin crew assumed these duties.

C-FYQO a Boeing 737-800 aircraft operated by Air Transat as flight TSC845 departed Puerto Plata/Gregorio Luperón Intl Dominican Republic (MDPP) for Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). After take-off the crew was unable to retract the flaps. A PAN PAN was declared and checklist items were completed. The aircraft returned to MDPP and landed uneventfully with flaps 5.

C-FYQO a Boeing 737-800 operated by Air Transat as flight TSC841 departed Cancún Intl Mexico (MMUN) for Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ). During the climb the aircraft experienced a flap disagree message upon flap retraction with the flaps staying at Flap 5. The checklist was completed a Pan Pan declared and a return to MMUN was initiated. Once established on the ILS for RWY 12R the crew tried extending the flaps using the alternate flap system; this created a flap asymmetry. A hold was requested and other checklist items were completed. The aircraft landed uneventfully with Flap 5 setting.

C-FOGJ a Boeing 767-300 aircraft was operating as WestJet flight 023 from London Gatwick (EGKK) to Vancouver Intl. (CYVR). After departing RWY 26L ATC issued a right turn to a heading of 090 degrees. The aircraft inadvertently turned to the left. ATC issued vectors to avoid a traffic conflict and the flight continued uneventfully.

N812AM a BAE 125-800A Hawker medivac aircraft operated by Airmed International had departed Gander Intl NL (CYQX) en route to Shannon Intl Ireland (EINN). While in cruise at FL330 the crew noted a drop of oil pressure on the left engine. The crew declared an emergency and returned to Gander where the aircraft landed safely. It was discovered that the oil cap on the pressure reservoir had become loose. The oil was replenished the cap was secured and the engine washed. The aircraft was returned to service.

C-FJOU an Airbus A321-200 aircraft operated by Air Canada rouge was operating as flight ROU1966 from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to Bridgetown/Grantley Adams Intl Barbados (TBPB). Shortly after departure the cabin crew noted a passenger exhibiting abnormal behaviour. Despite actions by the flight and cabin crews the individual’s behaviour worsened to the point that the threat of a bomb on board was made. The crew assisted by several passengers immediately restrained the individual. The flight crew declared an emergency and the individual's belongings were searched; no evidence of said device found. Based on the information made available the flight crew in consultation with the operator’s Operational Control Centre deemed the threat to be non-credible and decided to continue to TBPB. Upon arrival the aircraft was positioned at a secluded portion of the airport where local authorities detained the individual. A security sweep was performed with no concerns identified.

N545US a Boeing 757-200 aircraft operated by Delta Airlines as DAL446 was on a flight from New York/JFK Intl NY (KJFK) to Keflavik Intl Iceland (BIKF). While approaching waypoint N61W040 on their assigned North Atlantic Track (NAT) the flight crew requested a diversion due to adverse weather conditions at destination. ATC was unable to approve the requested FL360 for the diversion; however a diversion clearance was available at FL320. The crew elected to declare an emergency and deviated without a clearance in accordance with in-flight contingency procedures. Once level at FL320 the flight received a clearance to divert to Goose Bay NL (CYYR) where it landed without incident.

C-FIUV an Air Canada B777-300 operating as flight ACA32 departed Beijing/Capital China (ZBAA) for Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ). Shortly after departure a flight attendant was unable to continue duties. Their duties were assumed by the remaining cabin crew. The aircraft continued to destination.

C-FLSW a Sunwing Airlines Boeing 737-800 operating as flight SWG488 was crossing the Gulf of Mexico en route from Cancun Intl Mexico (MMUN) to Calgary Intl AB (CYYC) when the crew contacted Houston Center to request deviations due to weather. Subsequently SWG488 entered IMC conditions and was confirmed radar-identified by Houston. After approximately 5 minutes into IMC SWG488 received multiple failure indications in close succession (IAS Disagree ALT Disagree Master Caution - Engine EEC ALTN Low Airspeed Audio Warning AIRSPEED TOO LOW AT LIM CA Airspeed & Altitude erratic indications VNAV disconnect and Alpha Floor on MCP Panel). The crew declared PAN PAN with Houston Center and altered their heading to the east in order to exit IMC conditions. The failure indications continued for an additional 20 to 30 minutes before tapering off. Once out of IMC conditions and after the appropriate checklists were carried out failure indications ceased and the instruments returned to normal operation. The flight diverted to Orlando Intl FL (KMCO) without further incident.

D-CONU a Learjet 55 aircraft was about 30 nautical miles east of 50N 050W and proceeding north eastbound when it descended without clearance from FL410 to FL400 due to an outside air temperature exceedance. This caused a loss of separation with a westbound American Airlines Airbus A330-200 at FL400. The two aircraft came within approximately 50 nautical miles horizontally in lieu of the required 60 nautical miles. Air traffic control vectored the Learjet into radar coverage and descended it to FL290 for the remainder of its flight to destination.

G-YMMK a British Airways Boeing B777-263 aircraft operating as flight BA114 was en route from New York/John F Kennedy Intl NY (KJFK) to London/Heathrow Intl England (EGLL). While in cruise flight over the North Atlantic Ocean the cabin crew reported an electrical smell in the vicinity of seats 1K and 1F; however no smoke was reported. The smell did not dissipate despite the flight crew performing the smoke/fire/fumes checklist. The crew declared a PAN PAN and requested a diversion to Halifax/Stanfield Intl NS (CYHZ). BA114 landed at CYHZ without further incident.Maintenance personnel found that the power supply for seat 1F was hot to the touch and had an electrical burning smell. The power supply was removed and the aircraft was returned to service.

C-FNNH an Air Canada Boeing B777-200 aircraft operating as flight number ACA16 was en route from Hong Kong/Chek Lap Kok Intl China (VHHH) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) when there was a report of an acrid odour in the cabin. The in-flight entertainment (IFE) was switched off a PAN PAN was declared and a diversion to Tokyo/New Tokyo Intl Airport Japan (RJAA) was executed. Maintenance personnel deactivated the IFE system IFE cooling fan and the left lower recirculation fan in accordance with the MEL.

C-FITL an Air Canada B777-300 aircraft was operating as flight ACA30 from Beijing/Capital Intl China (ZBAA) to Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) when a flight attendant became ill shortly after departure and was unable to continue duties. Safety duties were distributed among the remaining cabin crew.

C-GTSO un Airbus A330-300 exploité par Air Transat sous l’indicatif de vol TSC499 effectuait un vol selon les règles de vol aux instruments depuis l’aéroport de Paris/Charles de Gaulle France (LFPG) à destination de l’aéroport de Montréal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL). Alors que l’appareil était en croisière à la verticale de Shannon Irlande (EINN) le commandant a été incommodé et n’a pu continuer son travail pour une période d’environ 30 minutes. À bord se trouvait un autre commandant de l’exploitant également qualifié sur l’Airbus A330-300 qui a assisté le premier officier jusqu’au retour en poste du premier commandant. L’appareil a continué jusqu’à destination et s’est posé sans encombre à CYUL.

C-GFAJ an Air Canada Airbus A330-300 was operating as flight ACA933 from Montreal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau Intl QC (CYUL) to Brussels Belgium (EBBR). During cruise flight a flight attendant became ill and was unable to continue their duties. The remaining cabin crew assumed all duties and the flight continued to destination.

The Air Canada Airbus A330-300 C-GHKR was operating as flight ACA844 from Calgary Intl AB (CYYC) to Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Germany (EDDF). While exiting the runway after landing in EDDF the flight crew observed an ECAM message \G HYD RSVR LO LVL\". The aircraft was stopped the checklist was completed and ARFF was requested to attend. The aircraft was then towed to the gate. The operator’s maintenance repaired a hydraulic pressure line in the wheel well as per AMM 20-23-11 and the aircraft was returned to service."

C-FCAE an Air Canada Boeing B767-300 operating as flight ACA810 Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to Istanbul/Atatürk Intl Turkey (LTBA) experienced a control issue during the landing roll-out on Runway 05 at LTBA. While the speed was below 80 knots the flight crew noticed the aircraft veering to the right side of the runway after the autobrakes had been disarmed. The aircraft stopped on the runway and the crew declared a MAYDAY with ATC. The brakes and steering were tested and with no issues noted the aircraft taxied to the gate. Subsequently the operator’s maintenance performed an autobrake/antiskid control unit BITE test a pedal brake test (IAW AMM 32-41-08) and a tires and wear pins inspection. All systems were considered serviceable and the aircraft was returned to service.

A Discovery Air Defence McDonnell-Douglas A-4N Skyhawk C-FGZO experienced an accumulation of dense white smoke in the cockpit during the take-off roll at Wittmund/Wittmundhafen Germany (ETNT). Reportedly the cockpit temperature became extremely hot while the temperature selection knob was centered. Consequently the oxygen system was immediately set to 100% and the smoke disappeared after the A-4N Checklist D-5 was executed. An emergency was declared and fuel burned off prior to an uneventful straight-in approach and landing at ETNT.

N858FD a Federal Express Boeing B777-FS2 aircraft operating as flight FDX38 was en route from Memphis Intl TN (KMEM) to Paris/Charles de Gaulle Intl France (LFPG). The crew was provided clearance for a climb via datalink from FL350 to FL370 at 1532Z. Two minutes later FDX38 reported level at FL370 via datalink. At 1535Z CS-TOK an Air Portugal Airbus A330-200 aircraft operating as flight TAP203 from Lisbon/Aeroporto da Portela de Sacavem Portugal (LPPT) to Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR) was cleared from FL340 to FL360. At that time a position report was received from FDX38 stating that it was at FL356 and climbing. An altitude confirmation request by ATC from FDX38 indicated the flight was at FL363 and climbing. Since FDX38 was not level at FL370 when TAP203 was cleared to climb to FL360 vertical and lateral flight separation was not assured.

C-GXAI an Air Inuit de Havilland DHC8-300 aircraft departed Kuujjuaq QC (CYVP) enroute to Nuuk Greenland (BGGH). While en route the crew noted a loss of hydraulic fluid on the number 2 system. The crew declared an emergency and returned to Kuujjuaq. The operator’s maintenance determined that the O-ring on the engine driven pump was damaged and was releasing oil. The pump was replaced the hydraulic system serviced and the aircraft was returned to service.

The Discovery Air Defence Services McDonell Douglas A4N Skyhawk C-FGZD was deployed away from its home base of Wittmund Germany on a military mission with the German Air Force at Gran Canaria Intl Spain (GCLP). While lowering the landing gear during the final approach the right main gear indication remained unsafe on barber pole. The pilot initiated a go around and after completion of the checklist the gear indication remained unsafe. An emergency was declared and a visual gear confirmation was obtained from the control tower. An approach and landing using the end arrestor cable was completed. The landing gear was pinned and the aircraft was towed back to the ramp. The operator's maintenance found a broken wire. Confirmation of the cause of the broken wire and the landing gear indication to follow.

C-FITL an Air Canada Boeing 777-300 operating as ACA873 experienced a second event that day similar to its first event (see A16F0035). Shortly after takeoff from London/Heathrow Intl UK (EGLL) where it diverted from Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Germany (EDDF) earlier in the day an acrid smell was once again detected near the galley at L2/R2. The power was isolated to the IFE and galleys and the aircraft returned to EGLL for maintenance.

C-FITL an Air Canada Boeing 777-300 was operating as ACA873 en route from Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Germany (EDDF) to Toronto/Lester B. Pearson Intl ON (CYYZ) when an acrid smell was detected in the forward galley shortly after departure. The QRH was actioned power to the IFE and galleys was isolated and 8 000 kgs of fuel was jettisoned. A PAN PAN was declared and the aircraft diverted to London/Heathrow Intl UK (EGLL).

C-FKIW a WestJet B737-700 was operating as WJA2152 from Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) to Puerto Vallarta/Licenciado Gustavo Díaz Ordaz Intl Mexico (MMPR) when a flight attendant was unable to perform duties. The remaining flight attendants assumed the duties and the aircraft landed uneventfully with EMS in attendance.

A WestJet Boeing 737-700 C-FIWJ was operating as flight WJA2253 from Loreto Intl Mexico (MMLT) to Calgary Intl AB (CYYC). During the take-off roll on Runway 34 the crew experienced a distinct and sudden yaw to the right at approximately 120 knots. The take-off was aborted and the aircraft was stopped on the runway; ARFF was requested as a precaution. There were no indications in the flight deck and external assessment revealed no issues. The aircraft was towed back to the terminal for further investigation. The Mexican DGAC has been notified and is investigating the incident. No cause has been determined yet and the operator’s investigation is in progress.

C-FZUB an Air Canada Airbus A320-200 operating as flight ACA2072 from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) to Punta Cana Intl Dominican Republic (MDPC) was en route when smoke was observed emanating from a seat-back video display unit. The Quick Reference Handbook was consulted. The smoke dissipated when the power to the entertainment system was removed. The flight continued to Punta Cana without further incident.The operator’s maintenance replaced the entertainment system's audio jack and Smart Video Display Unit at Seat 31D in accordance with AMM 44-10-55. Both were checked serviceable and the aircraft was returned to service.

Approximately one hour after departure on a scheduled flight from London/Heathrow Intl England (EGLL) to Calgary Intl AB (CYYC) ACA851 an Air Canada Boeing B787-8 aircraft (C-GHPT) declared an emergency (Pan Pan) after detecting an acrid odour in the cabin. The flight returned to EGLL and landed uneventfully with emergency services on standby.

The Virgin Atlantic B787 (registration G-VOOH) aeroplane was enroute from Heathrow (EGLL) to Miami (KMIA). While in Oceanic airspace the flight lost the Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Contract (ADS-C) connection making it ineligible for continued flight in reduced lateral separation measure (RLatSM) airspace. The flight was descended to a non-RLatSM altitude to regain required lateral separation from Virgin Atlantic A330-300 (registration G-VWAG) enroute from Manchester (EGCC) to Atlanta (KATL).

The Ken Borek Air Ltd DHC-6/300 Twin Otter C-GCKB was operating on a VFR flight from Skiway 20 Antarctica (NZSP) to Union Glacier Antarctica. On departure a left hand ski front harness attachment bolt sheared. This caused the left ski to dig into the snow on lift off. The takeoff was aborted and the aircraft ground looped to the left coming to rest at the side of the skiway. Damage was limited to flaps aileron and left wingtip fairing. There were no injuries.

Two aircraft transiting on the North Atlantic Track (NAT) system under reduced lateral separation minima (RLatSM) had a controller-pilot data link connections (CPDLC) connection loss with Gander ATC. This caused a conflict alert with ATC as several aircraft were 30 nautical miles in separation and now no longer met the RLatSM requirements. The data link issue was not resolved but the two aircraft that lost their data link were cleared descent or climb respectively to resolve the conflicts.

The Condor Boeing 767-300 aeroplane operating as flight CFG116 registration D-ABUI was en route from Frankfurt/Rhein-Main Intl Germany (EDDF) to Cancun Intl Mexico (MMUN) at FL310 when severe turbulence was encountered around position 61N/045W. The crew declared an emergency in order to descend while oceanic to FL280 where the turbulence abated. The aircraft continued on to destination and reported no injuries.

F-GSPP an Air France Boeing 777-200 aeroplane operating as flight AFR374 from Paris/Charles de Gaulle Intl France (LFPG) to Vancouver Intl BC (CYVR) was en route at FL360 when it encountered severe turbulence around position 59N/4630W. The crew declared an emergency and implemented oceanic offset and descent measures to depart the turbulence descending to FL290. The flight was cleared on course at this altitude and did not report any injuries.

Six aircraft transiting on the North Atlantic Track (NAT) system under reduced lateral separation minima (RLatSM) had a SITA (datalink provider) link outage as the datalink provider went temporarily offline. Another form of separation was established by ATC as aircraft were 30 nautical miles in trail and no longer met the RLatSM requirements. The datalink issue was resolved approximately one hour later and all connections were reestablished.

An American Airlines Boeing 767-323 N351AA was operating as AAL90 on a flight from Chicago/O’Hare Intl IL (KORD) to London/Heathrow Intl England (EGLL). While in cruise flight at about 53:00N/041:07W AAL90 declared a MAYDAY due to an electrical odour detected in the cockpit and requested to divert to St. John’s NL (CYYT). The flight coordinated with ATS and landed at CYYT without further incident.Maintenance personnel inspected the aircraft and determined that the left hand recirculation fan motor had failed causing the odour.

L’Airbus 330-300 exploité par Air Canada sous l’indicatif ACA833 effectuait un vol selon les règles de vol aux instruments depuis l’aéroport de Bruxelles Belgique (EBBR) à destination de l’aéroport de Montréal/Pierre Elliott Trudeau QC (CYUL) avec 217 passagers et 9 membres d’équipage. Alors que l’appareil était en croisière au début de la traversée Atlantique à environ 150 miles marins à l’est de la position N053 00/W015 00 un membre d’équipage de cabine a subi un malaise et n’a pu continuer son travail. L’appareil s’est posé sans encombre à CYUL.

The Virgin Atlantic Boeing 747-400 operating as VIR44 G-VGAL was en route from Las Vegas/Mc Carran Intl NV (KLAS) to London/Gatwick Intl UK (EGKK). The aircraft was flight planned at FL350 but was requested by ATC to climb to FL360. After climbing to FL360 the fuel low temp EICAS was triggered. The crew requested FL350 and was cleared to descent for warmer conditions. ATC advised that due to traffic further descent could only be permitted by declaring an emergency. The crew proceeded with declaring a PAN PAN and descended to FL330 then to FL310 to maintain the required fuel temperature. The flight progressed to destination without further issues.

C-FYJE an Air Canada rouge Airbus A319 aircraft operating as flight ROU1802 was on approach to Kingston/Norman Manley Intl Jamaica (MKJP) from Toronto/LBPIA ON (CYYZ) when the crew selected flaps down and received a flap fault. A go-around was conducted and the flight crew actioned the QRH in accordance with company policy and procedures. A PAN PAN was declared as a precaution and the aircraft performed an uneventful flapless landing with ARFF standing by. The occurrence is under review by the operator’s maintenance to determine the cause of the failure. The operator reported that maintenance found the right hand mechanical drive unit slightly out of rig causing the flap fault message. The unit was adjusted and further tests revealed no faults. The aircraft was returned to service.

N29124 a United Airlines Boeing 757 operating as UAL162 was on a flight from Glasgow Scotland (EGPF) to Newark/Liberty Intl NJ (KEWR). While in cruise the crew noted that the left windshield was cracked. The crew actioned the quick reference handbook to address the problem. They then declared a PAN PAN PAN conducted a track offset to descend and diverted to Gander NL (CYQX). The aircraft landed overweight at Gander without further incident. Maintenance personnel conducted an overweight inspection replaced the left windshield and the windshield heat controller. The aircraft was released back to service.

C-GTQX an Air Transat B737-800 operating as TSC783 was on its initial climb from Puerto Plata/Gregorio Luperón Intl Dominican Republic (MDPP) when a failure of the THS electric trim system occurred. The malfunction rendered the autopilot inoperative; the manual function of the THS trim system worked normally. An emergency was declared and the aircraft diverted and landed at Punta Cana Intl Dominican Republic (MDPC). Post - Air Transat submitted a report to Toronto region in iZone.
